intro: Mascagnia pubiflora var. typica, commonly known as the hairy mascagnia, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically pink or purple in color. The plant has hairy stems and leaves, which give it its common name. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in coastal areas or on rocky soils. Mascagnia pubiflora var. typica is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its vibrant blooms.
